Environment Lighting

The name environment lighting is from "10.2 Environment Lighting" of Real-Time Rendering Fourth Edition. The most important difference between environment light and global illumination is that the shading algorithm of the environment light is independent of the other positions on the surface except the shading position.

1. Diffuse Environment Lighting

Let L L ⁡ ( ω ) \displaystyle \operatorname{L_L}(\omega) LL​(ω) be the infinitely distant radiance distribution. Since the Lambert BRDF f ⁡ ( ω L → , ω V → ) = 1 π ρ s s \displaystyle \operatorname{f}(\overrightarrow{\omega_L}, \overrightarrow{\omega_V}) = \frac{1}{\pi} \rho_{ss} f(ωL​​,ωV​​)=π1​ρss​ is constant, we have L V ⁡ ( ω V → ) = ∫ Ω f ⁡ ( ω L → , ω V → ) L L ⁡ ( ω L → ) ( cos ⁡ θ L ) +   d ω L → = 1 π ρ s s ⋅ E \displaystyle \operatorname{L_V}(\overrightarrow{\omega_V}) = \int_\Omega \operatorname{f}(\overrightarrow{\omega_L}, \overrightarrow{\omega_V}) \operatorname{L_L}(\overrightarrow{\omega_L}) (\cos \theta_L)^+ \, d \overrightarrow{\omega_L} = \frac{1}{\pi} \rho_{ss} \cdot E LV​(ωV​​)=∫Ω​f(ωL​​,ωV​​)LL​(ωL​​)(cosθL​)+dωL​​=π1​ρss​⋅E where E ⁡ ( n → ) = ∫ Ω L L ⁡ ( ω L → ) ( cos ⁡ θ L ) +   d ω L → = ∫ Ω L L ⁡ ( ω L → ) ∣ n → ⋅ ω L → ∣   d ω L → \displaystyle \operatorname{E}(\overrightarrow{n}) = \int_\Omega \operatorname{L_L}(\overrightarrow{\omega_L}) (\cos \theta_L)^+ \, d \overrightarrow{\omega_L} = \int_\Omega \operatorname{L_L}(\overrightarrow{\omega_L}) |\overrightarrow{n} \cdot \overrightarrow{\omega_L}| \, d \overrightarrow{\omega_L} E(n)=∫Ω​LL​(ωL​​)(cosθL​)+dωL​​=∫Ω​LL​(ωL​​)∣n⋅ωL​​∣dωL​​ .
To keep the circular symmetry of the clamped cosine function, we try to calculate the lighting in tangent space where the normal direction is the Z axis (0, 0, 1). Evidently, we have ω L → = R ω T → \displaystyle \overrightarrow{\omega_L} = R \overrightarrow{\omega_T} ωL​​=RωT​​ where R is the rotation transform matrix. And we have E ⁡ ( n → ) = ∫ Ω L L ⁡ ( R ω T → ) ( cos ⁡ θ T ) +   d ω T → \displaystyle \operatorname{E}(\overrightarrow{n}) = \int_\Omega \operatorname{L_L}(R \overrightarrow{\omega_T}) (\cos \theta_T)^+ \, d \overrightarrow{\omega_T} E(n)=∫Ω​LL​(RωT​​)(cosθT​)+dωT​​ .
Let S H ⁡ \displaystyle \operatorname{\mathcal{SH}} SH be the SH (Spherical Harmonics) projection operation. Analogous to the convolution theorem, we have S H ⁡ ( ∫ Ω L L ⁡ ( R ω T → ) ( cos ⁡ θ T ) +   d ω T → ) = S H ⁡ ( L L ⁡ ( R ω T → ) ) S H ⁡ ( ( cos ⁡ θ T ) + ) \displaystyle \operatorname{\mathcal{SH}}(\int_\Omega \operatorname{L_L}(R \overrightarrow{\omega_T}) (\cos \theta_T)^+ \, d \overrightarrow{\omega_T}) = \operatorname{\mathcal{SH}}(\operatorname{L_L}(R \overrightarrow{\omega_T})) \operatorname{\mathcal{SH}}((\cos \theta_T)^+) SH(∫Ω​LL​(RωT​​)(cosθT​)+dωT​​)=SH(LL​(RωT​​))SH((cosθT​)+). Although S H ⁡ ( ( cos ⁡ θ T ) + ) \displaystyle \operatorname{\mathcal{SH}}((\cos \theta_T)^+) SH((cosθT​)+) is constant, S H ⁡ ( L L ⁡ ( R ω T → ) ) \displaystyle \operatorname{\mathcal{SH}}(\operatorname{L_L}(R \overrightarrow{\omega_T})) SH(LL​(RωT​​)) varies by the rotation transform matrix R and is difficult to calculate.
And let Z H ⁡ \displaystyle \operatorname{\mathcal{ZH}} ZH be the ZH (Zonal Harmonics) projection operation. By [Ramamoorthi 2001 A], due to the circular symmetry of ( cos ⁡ θ T ) + \displaystyle (\cos \theta_T)^+ (cosθT​)+ , we have S H ⁡ ( ∫ Ω L L ⁡ ( R ω T → ) ( cos ⁡ θ T ) +   d ω T → ) = 4 π 2 l + 1 S H ⁡ ( L L ⁡ ( ω L → ) ) Z H ⁡ ( ( cos ⁡ θ T ) + ) = 4 π 2 l + 1 L L m A l \displaystyle \operatorname{\mathcal{SH}}(\int_\Omega \operatorname{L_L}(R \overrightarrow{\omega_T}) (\cos \theta_T)^+ \, d \overrightarrow{\omega_T}) = \sqrt{\frac{4 \pi}{2l + 1}} \operatorname{\mathcal{SH}}(\operatorname{L_L}(\overrightarrow{\omega_L})) \operatorname{\mathcal{ZH}}((\cos \theta_T)^+) = \sqrt{\frac{4 \pi}{2l + 1}} L_L^m A_l SH(∫Ω​LL​(RωT​​)(cosθT​)+dωT​​)=2l+14π​​SH(LL​(ωL​​))ZH((cosθT​)+)=2l+14π​​LLm​Al​ , where L L m = S H ⁡ ( L L ⁡ ( ω L → ) ) \displaystyle L_L^m = \operatorname{\mathcal{SH}}(\operatorname{L_L}(\overrightarrow{\omega_L})) LLm​=SH(LL​(ωL​​)) and A l = Z H ⁡ ( ( cos ⁡ θ T ) + ) \displaystyle A_l = \operatorname{\mathcal{ZH}}((\cos \theta_T)^+) Al​=ZH((cosθT​)+), which does NOT depend on the rotation transform matrix R.

1-1. Cubemap Texel Solid Angle

We merely use numerical quadrature rather than Monte Carlo integration to integrate over the cubemap. But it should be noted that the solid angle subtended by each texel of the cubemap is NOT the same. Let u and v be the texcoord of the cubemap. By "Equation (5.6)" of PBR Book, we have d ω = d A cos ⁡ θ r 2 = d A ⋅ cos ⁡ θ ⋅ 1 r 2 = ( 1 − ( − 1 ) ) ∗ ( 1 − ( − 1 ) ) cubesize.u ∗ cubesize.v ⋅ 1 1 2 + u 2 + v 2 ⋅ 1 1 2 + u 2 + v 2 = 1 cubesize.u ∗ cubesize.v ⋅ 4 1 2 + u 2 + v 2 ⋅ ( 1 2 + u 2 + v 2 ) \displaystyle d\omega = \frac{dA \cos \theta}{r^2} = dA \cdot \cos \theta \cdot \frac{1}{r^2} = \frac{(1 - (-1))*(1 - (-1))}{\text{cubesize.u}*\text{cubesize.v}} \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{1^2 + u^2 +v^2}} \cdot \frac{1}{1^2 + u^2 +v^2} = \frac{1}{\text{cubesize.u}*\text{cubesize.v}} \cdot \frac{4}{\sqrt{1^2 + u^2 +v^2} \cdot (1^2 + u^2 +v^2)} dω=r2dAcosθ​=dA⋅cosθ⋅r21​=cubesize.u∗cubesize.v(1−(−1))∗(1−(−1))​⋅12+u2+v2​1​⋅12+u2+v21​=cubesize.u∗cubesize.v1​⋅12+u2+v2​⋅(12+u2+v2)4​. Actually the pseudo code "fWt = 4/(sqrt(fTmp)*fTmp)" by "Projection from Cube Maps" of [Sloan 2008] is exactly the 4 1 2 + u 2 + v 2 ⋅ ( 1 2 + u 2 + v 2 ) \displaystyle \frac{4}{\sqrt{1^2 + u^2 +v^2} \cdot (1^2 + u^2 +v^2)} 12+u2+v2​⋅(12+u2+v2)4​. The common divisor 1 cubesize.u ∗ cubesize.v \displaystyle \frac{1}{\text{cubesize.u}*\text{cubesize.v}} cubesize.u∗cubesize.v1​ can be reduced, and thus is NOT calculated by [Sloan 2008]. The solid angle is calculated by SHProjectCubeMap in DirectXMath and DiffuseIrradianceCopyPS in UE4.

% here is the MATLAB code which verifies the meaning of "fWt = 4/(sqrt(fTmp)*fTmp)".

% retrieved by "textureSize(GLSL)" or "GetDimensions(HLSL)".
cube_size_u = 4096.0;
cube_size_v = 4096.0;

[ u, v ] = meshgrid(linspace(-1.0, 1.0, cube_size_u), linspace(-1.0, 1.0, cube_size_v));

% the common divisor "1/(cube_size_u*cube_size_v)" can be reduced, and thus is NOT calculated in the "fWt = 4/(sqrt(fTmp)*fTmp)".
d_a = (1.0 - (-1.0)) .* (1.0 - (-1.0)) ./ cube_size_u ./ cube_size_v;
r_2 = 1.0 .* 1.0 + u .* u + v .* v;
cos_theta = 1.0 ./ sqrt(r_2);
d_omega = d_a .* cos_theta ./ r_2;

% "numerical_omega" and "groundtruth_omega" are expected to be the same.
numerical_omega = sum(sum(d_omega));
groundtruth_omega = 4.0 .* pi .* 1.0 .* 1.0 / 6.0;

% output: "numerical:2.093936 groundtruth:2.094395".
printf("numerical:%f groundtruth:%f\n", numerical_omega, groundtruth_omega);

1-4. Form Factor

"Appendix A10" of [Sloan 2008] proposed a more efficient approach to reconstruct from SH basis than [Ramamoorthi 2001 B]. This approach is used by SampleSH9 in Unity3D and GetSkySHDiffuse in UE4.
However, it was form factor rather than irradiance that "Appendix A10" of [Sloan 2008] calculated. Although the terms irradiance and form factor may be interchangeably used, technically irradiance should NOT be divided by π \displaystyle \pi π. This means that E ⁡ ( n → ) = π F ⁡ ( n → ) \displaystyle \operatorname{E}(\overrightarrow{n}) = \pi \operatorname{F}(\overrightarrow{n}) E(n)=πF(n). This form factor is calculated by PackCoefficients in Unity3D, and SetupSkyIrradianceEnvironmentMapConstantsFromSkyIrradiance and ComputeSkyEnvMapDiffuseIrradianceCS in UE4.
And since the value reconstructed from SH basis is form factor rather than irradiance, it should be multiplied by albedo rather than Lambert BRDF. This multiplication is calculated by GetDiffuseOrDefaultColor in Unity3D and EnvBRDFApproxFullyRough in UE4.

2-1. Monte Carlo Integration

2-1-1. PDF

By "Figure 6" of [Walter 2007] and "Figure 14.4" of PBR Book, we have the relationship between d ω H → \displaystyle d \overrightarrow{\omega_H} dωH​​ and d ω L → \displaystyle d \overrightarrow{\omega_L} dωL​​ that d ω H → = ∣ ω L → ⋅ ω H → ∣ ∥ ω L → + ω V → ∥ 2 d ω L → = ∣ ω L → ⋅ ω H → ∣ ∥ ω L → + ( 2 ( ω L → ⋅ ω H → ) ω H → − ω L → ) ∥ 2 d ω V → = ∣ ω L → ⋅ ω H → ∣ 4 ( ω L → ⋅ ω H → ) 2 ∥ ω H → ∥ 2 d ω L → = 1 4 ∣ ω L → ⋅ ω H → ∣ d ω L → \displaystyle d \overrightarrow{\omega_H} = \frac{|\overrightarrow{\omega_L} \cdot \overrightarrow{\omega_H}|}{{\|\overrightarrow{\omega_L} + \overrightarrow{\omega_V}\|}^2} d \overrightarrow{\omega_L} = \frac{|\overrightarrow{\omega_L} \cdot \overrightarrow{\omega_H}|}{{\|\overrightarrow{\omega_L} + (2 (\overrightarrow{\omega_L} \cdot \overrightarrow{\omega_H})\overrightarrow{\omega_H} - \overrightarrow{\omega_L})\|}^2} d \overrightarrow{\omega_V} = \frac{|\overrightarrow{\omega_L} \cdot \overrightarrow{\omega_H}|}{4{(\overrightarrow{\omega_L} \cdot \overrightarrow{\omega_H})}^2 {\|\overrightarrow{\omega_H}\|}^2} d \overrightarrow{\omega_L} = \frac{1}{4 |\overrightarrow{\omega_L} \cdot \overrightarrow{\omega_H}|} d \overrightarrow{\omega_L} dωH​​=∥ωL​​+ωV​​∥2∣ωL​​⋅ωH​​∣​dωL​​=∥ωL​​+(2(ωL​​⋅ωH​​)ωH​​−ωL​​)∥2∣ωL​​⋅ωH​​∣​dωV​​=4(ωL​​⋅ωH​​)2∥ωH​​∥2∣ωL​​⋅ωH​​∣​dωL​​=4∣ωL​​⋅ωH​​∣1​dωL​​ . Note that since the subtended area on the sphere surface remains the same, the d ω H → \displaystyle d \overrightarrow{\omega_H} dωH​​ can be calculated even if the ω H → \displaystyle \overrightarrow{\omega_H} ωH​​ is NOT normalized.

By "Figure 8.15" of PBR Book, we have ∫ Ω D ⁡ ( ω H → ) ( cos ⁡ θ H ) +   d ω H → = 1 \displaystyle \int_{\Omega} \operatorname{D}(\overrightarrow{\omega_H}) ( \cos \theta_H )^+ \, d \overrightarrow{\omega_H} = 1 ∫Ω​D(ωH​​)(cosθH​)+dωH​​=1. According to the relationship between d ω H → \displaystyle d \overrightarrow{\omega_H} dωH​​ and d ω L → \displaystyle d \overrightarrow{\omega_L} dωL​​ , we have ∫ Ω D ⁡ ( ω H → ) ( cos ⁡ θ H ) +   d ω H → = ∫ Ω D ⁡ ( ω H → ) ( cos ⁡ θ H ) + 1 4 ∣ ω L → ⋅ ω H → ∣   d ω L → = 1 \displaystyle \int_{\Omega} \operatorname{D}(\overrightarrow{\omega_H}) ( \cos \theta_H )^+ \, d \overrightarrow{\omega_H} = \int_{\Omega} \operatorname{D}(\overrightarrow{\omega_H}) ( \cos \theta_H )^+ \frac{1}{4 |\overrightarrow{\omega_L} \cdot \overrightarrow{\omega_H}|} \, d \overrightarrow{\omega_L} = 1 ∫Ω​D(ωH​​)(cosθH​)+dωH​​=∫Ω​D(ωH​​)(cosθH​)+4∣ωL​​⋅ωH​​∣1​dωL​​=1. Evidently, this normalized function can be used as the PDF p ⁡ ( ω L → ) = D ⁡ ( ω H → ) ( cos ⁡ θ H ) + 1 4 ∣ ω L → ⋅ ω H → ∣ \displaystyle \operatorname{p}(\overrightarrow{\omega_L}) = \operatorname{D}(\overrightarrow{\omega_H}) ( \cos \theta_H )^+ \frac{1}{4 |\overrightarrow{\omega_L} \cdot \overrightarrow{\omega_H}|} p(ωL​​)=D(ωH​​)(cosθH​)+4∣ωL​​⋅ωH​​∣1​.

TODO: Although this is literally the PDF used by UE4, the VNDF by [Heitz 2018] is a better alternative to be used as the PDF.

By "Equation (13.3)" of PBR Book, we have R ⁡ ( ω V → ) = ∫ Ω f ⁡ ( ω L → , ω V → ) ( cos ⁡ θ L ) +   d ω L → = 1 N ∑ i = 1 N f ⁡ ( ω L → , ω V → ) ( cos ⁡ θ L ) + p ⁡ ( ω L → , ω V → ) \displaystyle \operatorname{R}(\overrightarrow{\omega_V}) = \int_\Omega \operatorname{f}(\overrightarrow{\omega_L}, \overrightarrow{\omega_V}) (\cos \theta_L)^+ \, d \overrightarrow{\omega_L} = \frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^N \frac{\operatorname{f}(\overrightarrow{\omega_L}, \overrightarrow{\omega_V}) (\cos \theta_L)^+}{\displaystyle \operatorname{p}(\overrightarrow{\omega_L}, \overrightarrow{\omega_V})} R(ωV​​)=∫Ω​f(ωL​​,ωV​​)(cosθL​)+dωL​​=N1​i=1∑N​p(ωL​​,ωV​​)f(ωL​​,ωV​​)(cosθL​)+​. Evidently, D ⁡ ( ω H → ) \displaystyle \operatorname{D}(\overrightarrow{\omega_H}) D(ωH​​) exists in both f ⁡ ( ω L → , ω V → ) \displaystyle \operatorname{f}(\overrightarrow{\omega_L}, \overrightarrow{\omega_V}) f(ωL​​,ωV​​) and p ⁡ ( ω L → , ω V → ) \displaystyle \operatorname{p}(\overrightarrow{\omega_L}, \overrightarrow{\omega_V}) p(ωL​​,ωV​​), and thus D ⁡ ( ω H → ) \displaystyle \operatorname{D}(\overrightarrow{\omega_H}) D(ωH​​) can be omitted when calculating the integral.

2-1-2. Sampling Trowbridge-Reitz Distribution

When D ⁡ ( ω H → ) \displaystyle \operatorname{D}(\overrightarrow{\omega_H}) D(ωH​​) is Beckmann–Spizzichino ("Equation (8.9)" of PBR Book) distribution, the derivation of the sampling is provided by "Equation (14.1)" of PBR Book.

Analogously, the sampling can be derived when D ⁡ ( ω H → ) \displaystyle \operatorname{D}(\overrightarrow{\omega_H}) D(ωH​​) is isotropic Trowbridge-Reitz ("Equation (8.11)" of PBR Book) distribution, namely, GGX distribution. Since the distribution is isotropic, we have p ⁡ ( ϕ ∣ θ H ) = 1 2 π ⇒ ϕ = 2 π ξ 2 \displaystyle \displaystyle \operatorname{p}(\phi | \theta_H) = \frac{1}{2 \pi} \Rightarrow \phi = 2 \pi \xi_2 p(ϕ∣θH​)=2π1​⇒ϕ=2πξ2​ . Since the PDF is p ⁡ ( ω H → ) = D ⁡ ( ω H → ) ( cos ⁡ θ H ) + \displaystyle \operatorname{p}(\overrightarrow{\omega_H}) = \operatorname{D}(\overrightarrow{\omega_H}) ( \cos \theta_H )^+ p(ωH​​)=D(ωH​​)(cosθH​)+ , we have the marginal PDF p ⁡ ( θ H ) = ∫ 0 2 π p ⁡ ( θ H , ϕ )   d ϕ = ∫ 0 2 π p ⁡ ( ω H → ) sin ⁡ ω H   d ϕ = ∫ 0 2 π D ⁡ ( ω H → ) ( cos ⁡ θ H ) + sin ⁡ ω H   d ϕ = 2 π D ⁡ ( ω H → ) ( cos ⁡ θ H ) + sin ⁡ ω H \displaystyle \operatorname{p}(\theta_H) = \int_0^{2 \pi} \operatorname{p}(\theta_H, \phi) \, d \phi = \int_0^{2 \pi} \operatorname{p}(\overrightarrow{\omega_H}) \sin \omega_H \, d \phi = \int_0^{2 \pi} \operatorname{D}(\overrightarrow{\omega_H}) ( \cos \theta_H )^+ \sin \omega_H \, d \phi = 2 \pi \operatorname{D}(\overrightarrow{\omega_H}) ( \cos \theta_H )^+ \sin \omega_H p(θH​)=∫02π​p(θH​,ϕ)dϕ=∫02π​p(ωH​​)sinωH​dϕ=∫02π​D(ωH​​)(cosθH​)+sinωH​dϕ=2πD(ωH​​)(cosθH​)+sinωH​ and the CDF P ⁡ ( θ H ) = ∫ 0 θ H ′ p ⁡ ( θ H ′ )   d θ H ′ = ξ 1 \displaystyle \operatorname{P}(\theta_H) = \int_0^{\theta'_H} \operatorname{p}(\theta'_H) \, d \theta'_H = \xi_1 P(θH​)=∫0θH′​​p(θH′​)dθH′​=ξ1​ . Fortunately, this CDF is closed-form and we have tan ⁡ 2 θ H = α 2 ξ 1 1 − ξ 1 ⇒ cos ⁡ θ H = 1 1 + tan ⁡ 2 θ H = 1 − ξ 1 1 + ( α 2 − 1 ) ξ 1 \displaystyle \tan^2 \theta_H = \frac{\alpha^2 \xi_1}{1 - \xi_1} \Rightarrow \cos \theta_H = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1 + \tan^2 \theta_H}} = \sqrt{\frac{1 - \xi_1}{1 + (\alpha^2 - 1) \xi_1}} tan2θH​=1−ξ1​α2ξ1​​⇒cosθH​=1+tan2θH​​1​=1+(α2−1)ξ1​1−ξ1​​​ .

Actually, when the PDF is the VNDF by [Heitz 2018], the derivation of the sampling is provided by "Equation (14.2)" of PBR Book.

The sampling is caculated by TrowbridgeReitzDistribution::Sample_wh in PBRT-V3, ImportanceSampleGGX in UE4 and SampleGGXDir in Unity3D.

2-1-3. Low-Discrepancy

By "20.3 Quasirandom Low-Discrepancy Sequences" of [Colbert 2007], Quasi Monte Carlo ("13.8.2 Quasi Monte Carlo" of PBR Book) is used and the pseudo-random sequence is replaced by the low-discrepancy Hammersley sequence ("7.4.1 Hammersley and Halton Sequences" of PBR Book).

The Hammersley sequence is calcuated by Hammersley in UE4 and Hammersley2d in Unity3D. And the Fibonacci sequence is calculated by FIBONACCI_SEQUENCE_ANGLE in UE4 and Fibonacci2d in Unity3D.

2-2. DFG Term

Actually, by "Equation (9.9)" of Real-Time Rendering Fourth Edition, the DFG term is the HDR (Hemispherical Directional Reflectance) R ⁡ ( ω V → ) = ∫ Ω f ⁡ ( ω L → , ω V → ) ( cos ⁡ θ L ) +   d ω L = ∫ Ω f ⁡ ( ω L → , ω V → ) ( ( 0 , 0 , 1 ) → ⋅ ω L → ) +   d ω L \displaystyle \operatorname{R}(\overrightarrow{\omega_V}) = \int_\Omega \operatorname{f}(\overrightarrow{\omega_L}, \overrightarrow{\omega_V}) (\cos \theta_L)^+ \, d \omega_L = \int_\Omega \operatorname{f}(\overrightarrow{\omega_L}, \overrightarrow{\omega_V}) (\overrightarrow{(0,0,1)} \cdot \overrightarrow{\omega_L})^+ \, d \omega_L R(ωV​​)=∫Ω​f(ωL​​,ωV​​)(cosθL​)+dωL​=∫Ω​f(ωL​​,ωV​​)((0,0,1)​⋅ωL​​)+dωL​ . Since this integral can be calculated in the tangent space where the normal direction is (0, 0, 1), this integral is independent of the normal direction and can be determined by the view direction in tangent space alone.

Actually, by "Equation (9)" of [Karis 2013], the Fresnel term can be treated separately, and we have R ⁡ ( ω V → ) = ∫ Ω [ F 0 + ( F 90 − F 0 ) ( 1.0 − ω V → ⋅ ω H → ) 5 ] DV ⁡ ( ω L → , ω V → )   d ω L = F 0 ⋅ n R ⁡ ( ω V → ) + F 90 ⋅ n G ⁡ ( ω V → ) \displaystyle \operatorname{R}(\overrightarrow{\omega_V}) = \int_\Omega [F_0 + (F_{90} - F_0) {(1.0 - \overrightarrow{\omega_V} \cdot \overrightarrow{\omega_H})}^5] \operatorname{DV}(\overrightarrow{\omega_L}, \overrightarrow{\omega_V}) \, d \omega_L = F_0 \cdot \operatorname{n_R}(\overrightarrow{\omega_V}) + F_{90} \cdot \operatorname{n_G}(\overrightarrow{\omega_V}) R(ωV​​)=∫Ω​[F0​+(F90​−F0​)(1.0−ωV​​⋅ωH​​)5]DV(ωL​​,ωV​​)dωL​=F0​⋅nR​(ωV​​)+F90​⋅nG​(ωV​​) where n R ⁡ ( ω V → ) = ∫ Ω [ 1.0 − ( 1.0 − ω V → ⋅ ω H → ) 5 ] DV ⁡ ( ω L → , ω V → )   d ω L \displaystyle \operatorname{n_R}(\overrightarrow{\omega_V}) = \int_\Omega [1.0 - {(1.0 - \overrightarrow{\omega_V} \cdot \overrightarrow{\omega_H})}^5] \operatorname{DV}(\overrightarrow{\omega_L}, \overrightarrow{\omega_V}) \, d \omega_L nR​(ωV​​)=∫Ω​[1.0−(1.0−ωV​​⋅ωH​​)5]DV(ωL​​,ωV​​)dωL​ and n G ⁡ ( ω V → ) = ∫ Ω ( 1.0 − ω V → ⋅ ω H → ) 5 DV ⁡ ( ω L → , ω V → )   d ω L \displaystyle \operatorname{n_G}(\overrightarrow{\omega_V}) = \int_\Omega {(1.0 - \overrightarrow{\omega_V} \cdot \overrightarrow{\omega_H})}^5 \operatorname{DV}(\overrightarrow{\omega_L}, \overrightarrow{\omega_V}) \, d \omega_L nG​(ωV​​)=∫Ω​(1.0−ωV​​⋅ωH​​)5DV(ωL​​,ωV​​)dωL​ . Evidently, n R ⁡ ( ω V → ) \displaystyle \operatorname{n_R}(\overrightarrow{\omega_V}) nR​(ωV​​) and n G ⁡ ( ω V → ) \displaystyle \operatorname{n_G}(\overrightarrow{\omega_V}) nG​(ωV​​) can be stored in the LUT.

The DFG term is pre-integrated by InitializeFeatureLevelDependentTextures in UE4 and IntegrateGGXAndDisneyDiffuseFGD in Unity3D, and used by EnvBRDF in UE4 and GetPreIntegratedFGDGGXAndDisneyDiffuse in Unity3D.

2-3. LD Term

2-3-1. Split Integral Approximation

By "Equation (13.3)" of PBR Book, we have LD ⁡ ( ω V → ) = ∫ Ω f ⁡ ( ω L → , ω V → ) L L ⁡ ( ω L → ) ( cos ⁡ θ L ) +   d ω L → ∫ Ω f ⁡ ( ω L → , ω V → ) ( cos ⁡ θ L ) +   d ω L → = 1 N ∑ i = 1 N f ⁡ ( + ∑ i = 1 N F ⋅ G ⋅ ( LdotH ) + ( NdotV ) + ⋅ ( NdotH ) + = ∑ i = 1 N L ⋅ Weight ∑ i = 1 N Weight \operatorname{LD}(\overrightarrow{\omega_V}) = \frac{\int_\Omega This means that when L L ⁡ ( ω L → ) \displaystyle \operatorname{L_L}(\overrightarrow{\omega_L}) LL​(ωL​​) is constant, no matter what Weight term we use, we will always have an exact match.

By [Karis 2013], assuming that the Weight term equals ( cos ⁡ θ L ) + \displaystyle (\cos \theta_L)^+ (cosθL​)+ , we have the split integral approximation LD ⁡ ( ω V → ) = ∑ i = 1 N L ⋅ Weight ∑ i = 1 N Weight ≈ ∑ i = 1 N L ⋅ ( NdotL ) + ∑ i = 1 N ( NdotL ) + \displaystyle \operatorname{LD}(\overrightarrow{\omega_V}) = \frac{\sum_{i=1}^N \text{L} \cdot \text{Weight}}{\sum_{i=1}^N \text{Weight}} \approx \frac{\sum_{i=1}^N \text{L} \cdot (\text{NdotL})^+}{\sum_{i=1}^N (\text{NdotL})^+} LD(ωV​​)=∑i=1N​Weight∑i=1N​L⋅Weight​≈∑i=1N​(NdotL)+∑i=1N​L⋅(NdotL)+​.

The LD term is pre-integrated by FilterCS in UE4 and IntegrateLD in Unity3D, and used by GetSkyLightReflection in UE4 and SampleEnvWithDistanceBaseRoughness in Unity3D.

2-3-2. Dimensions

Ideally, we should use three dimensions: N(world space), NdotV and roughness to look up the pre-integrated LD term.

By [Karis 2013], roughness is mapped to mip level. The mapping between roughness and mip level is calculated by ComputeReflectionCaptureMipFromRoughness and ComputeReflectionCaptureRoughnessFromMip in UE4, and PerceptualRoughnessToMipmapLevel and MipmapLevelToPerceptualRoughness by Unity3D.

However, we do NOT have enough remaining dimensions to store both N(world space) and NdotV. By [Karis 2013], we assume "V = N" when pre-integrating the LD term, while the reflection direction R is used to look up the LD term when rendering. By "Figure 10.37" of Real-Time Rendering Fourth Edition, [Lagarde 2014] deviates the reflection direction to the normal direction to reduce the error generated by the non-clipped specular lobe.

The deviation is calculated by GetOffSpecularPeakReflectionDir in UE4 and GetSpecularDominantDir in Unity3D.

TODO: If we use the Paraboloid Map, perhaps we can use the 3D texture and provide one dimension for the NdotV. Thus, we can use both N and NdotV to look up the LD term.
